remarks: The exponential function of an imaginary number maps any interval of length ` 2 _pi ` one-to-one onto the unit circle.  (Contributed by Paul Chapman, 16-Mar-2008.)  (Proof shortened by Mario Carneiro, 13-May-2014.)
statement:
efif1o.1 $e |- F = ( w e. D |-> ( exp ` ( _i x. w ) ) ) $.
efif1o.2 $e |- C = ( `' abs " { 1 } ) $.
efif1olem4.3 $e |- ( ph -> D C_ RR ) $.
efif1olem4.4 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( x e. D /\ y e. D ) ) -> ( abs ` ( x - y ) ) < ( 2 x. _pi ) ) $.
efif1olem4.5 $e |- ( ( ph /\ z e. RR ) -> E. y e. D ( ( z - y ) / ( 2 x. _pi ) ) e. ZZ ) $.
efif1olem4.6 $e |- S = ( sin |` ( -u ( _pi / 2 ) [,] ( _pi / 2 ) ) ) $.
efif1olem4 $p |- ( ph -> F : D -1-1-onto-> C ) $.
$d C w x y $.
$d D w x y z $.
$d F x y $.
$d S y z $.
$d ph w x y z $.
